meta.title: Operation Blackout: Ransomware
meta.description: A critical server in HR has been encrypted. The attackers are demanding 50 BTC. The clock is ticking — your team must contain, communicate, and recover before the damage becomes irreversible.

questions.context: SOC Alert: Highly anomalous outbound traffic detected from the HR file server to a known C2 IP address in Eastern Europe. Multiple .encrypted file extensions appearing across shared drives.
questions.text: What is your immediate containment strategy?

options.label: Isolate the HR VLAN, block the C2 IP at the firewall edge, and initiate automated IOC sweeps across all subnets.
options.feedback_text: Yes, and… Textbook response. The VLAN isolation stops lateral movement while the IOC sweep catches a dormant beacon in the Finance subnet before it activates. Your EDR auto-quarantines the payload.

options.label: Isolate only the HR VLAN and begin forensic imaging of the compromised server.
options.feedback_text: Yes, but… Good containment of the HR segment. However, the forensic imaging delays your response by 20 minutes. During that time, the attacker's second-stage payload executes on a development server outside the HR VLAN.

options.label: Monitor the traffic for 15 more minutes to gather threat intelligence before acting.
options.feedback_text: No, but… Critical delay. The ransomware spreads to Finance during your observation window. However, your monitoring did capture the full C2 protocol handshake, which later proves invaluable for attribution.

options.label: Sever the internet connection for the entire HQ immediately without notifying anyone.
options.feedback_text: No, and… You stopped the lateral spread, but killed all legitimate business operations. CEO's live investor call drops mid-sentence. VPN tunnels to branch offices collapse. Worse — the ransomware had an offline encryption mode that continues working without C2.

questions.context: The attackers have posted a sample of employee PII data on a dark-web leak site. Journalists from two national outlets are calling your PR department for comment.
questions.text: How do you handle the external communication crisis?

options.label: Proactively disclose the breach with a detailed transparency report and coordinate with affected employees directly.
options.feedback_text: Yes, and… Bold and transparent. Analysts praise your mature incident response posture. The transparency report goes viral in a positive way — three other companies reach out to benchmark their IR process against yours.

options.label: Issue a holding statement: 'We are aware of an incident and are actively investigating with law enforcement.'
options.feedback_text: Yes, but… Standard procedure that keeps panic low. However, the vagueness of the statement leads to rumor-fueled speculation on social media. Employee morale drops slightly.

options.label: Redirect all media inquiries to legal and refuse any comment until the investigation concludes.
options.feedback_text: No, but… The silence fuels negative coverage. However, your legal team successfully prevents any statements that could create regulatory liability later.

options.label: Deny any breach publicly and threaten journalists with legal action for defamation.
options.feedback_text: No, and… The leaked data is already verified. Your denial is immediately debunked. #DataBreach trends nationally and your company becomes a case study in crisis mismanagement. Board members demand an explanation.

questions.context: The attackers have sent a ransom note demanding 50 BTC (~$2.1M). They claim to have exfiltrated 150GB of data including employee SSNs, medical records, and executive emails. They threaten to publish everything in 48 hours.
questions.text: How do you respond to the ransom demand?

options.label: Engage a professional ransomware negotiator while the DFIR team maps out backup recovery options in parallel.
options.feedback_text: Yes, and… The negotiator extends the deadline by 72 hours. Meanwhile, DFIR discovers that 80% of encrypted data exists in immutable backups. The negotiation bought enough time for a near-complete recovery without paying.

options.label: Refuse to pay and focus entirely on restoring from backups.
options.feedback_text: Yes, but… Your backup strategy works — systems are restored within 36 hours. However, the attackers publish the stolen 150GB of data. Employee class-action is now likely.

options.label: Pay the ransom through an intermediary cryptocurrency service.
options.feedback_text: No, but… You receive a decryption key and it works on 70% of files. The attackers keep their word and don't publish. However, law enforcement is disappointed and your cyber insurance premium triples.

options.label: Ignore the ransom note entirely and tell no one about the exfiltration claim.
options.feedback_text: No, and… The 48 hours pass and the full data dump goes public. Regulators open a formal investigation for failure to notify. Your CISO's credibility is destroyed. Multiple executives begin updating their resumes.

questions.context: Your DFIR team has identified the initial attack vector: a phishing email with a malicious macro sent to an HR coordinator 5 days ago. The attacker used stolen credentials to move laterally via RDP. EDR logs show the attacker had domain admin privileges for 3 days.
questions.text: What is your priority for recovery and hardening?

options.label: Force a company-wide password reset, disable RDP, deploy MFA on all privileged accounts, and audit for rogue service accounts.
options.feedback_text: Yes, and… Comprehensive response. The audit discovers two backdoor accounts the attacker created. MFA prevents all further credential abuse. Your SOC uses the incident artifacts to create new detection signatures that catch 3 similar campaigns at partner organizations.

options.label: Force a company-wide password reset and disable RDP across all environments.
options.feedback_text: Yes, but… The password reset closes the main attack path. However, without the service account audit, a dormant backdoor account remains active for another 48 hours before being detected by routine monitoring.

options.label: Only reset passwords for accounts known to be compromised and increase monitoring.
options.feedback_text: No, but… Insufficient scope. The attacker had domain admin — they created accounts you don't know about yet. However, your increased monitoring does catch re-entry within 6 hours, limiting additional damage.

options.label: Take all domain controllers offline and rebuild Active Directory from scratch.
options.feedback_text: No, and… Nuclear option with no planning. All authentication services go down for 12+ hours. Employees can't log in, email is dead, VPN is broken. The business grinds to a halt, and the board questions whether your team is competent enough to handle the crisis.

questions.context: The immediate crisis is stabilizing. The board has called an emergency meeting and wants a post-incident action plan. Regulators have sent a formal inquiry letter. Employee morale is low — several key engineers are considering leaving.
questions.text: What is your strategic recommendation to the board?

options.label: Propose a 90-day security overhaul: zero-trust architecture, mandatory training, dedicated IR team, and commission an independent third-party audit with public findings.
options.feedback_text: Yes, and… The board approves a $3M budget. The public audit commitment earns praise from the security community and regulators. Two key engineers who were planning to leave decide to stay, excited by the investment in security infrastructure.

options.label: Propose a 90-day security overhaul: new EDR, zero-trust architecture, and mandatory security training.
options.feedback_text: Yes, but… The board approves a $2M budget. Good progress, but without the third-party audit commitment, regulators remain skeptical. One key engineer still leaves for a competitor.

options.label: Commission an independent third-party audit but delay major infrastructure changes until findings are available.
options.feedback_text: No, but… The audit commitment shows good faith to regulators. However, the 6-week delay before any hardening begins leaves the organization vulnerable. Employees interpret the inaction as leadership paralysis.

options.label: Recommend minimal changes — patch the specific vulnerability and move on to minimize cost disruption.
options.feedback_text: No, and… Regulators see through the deflection and issue a formal warning with the threat of significant fines. Employee trust collapses. Your CISO updates their LinkedIn. The board starts discussing a leadership change in IT.

questions.context: DFIR has obtained a memory dump from the initial compromised HR server. The malware sample shows characteristics of a known APT group's toolkit. Your threat intel platform shows IOCs matching campaigns against three other organizations in your sector this month.
questions.text: How do you leverage this forensic intelligence?

options.label: Extract all IOCs, share them through your ISAC, deploy YARA rules across all endpoints, and correlate with historical logs for earlier compromise indicators.
options.feedback_text: Yes, and… Your YARA rules catch a dormant second-stage implant on the CFO's laptop that hadn't activated yet. The ISAC sharing earns goodwill and two partner organizations share back additional TTPs that help your investigation.

options.label: Deploy detection signatures based on extracted IOCs across your own endpoints and continue deeper malware analysis.
options.feedback_text: Yes, but… Good internal defense hardening. The deeper analysis reveals a custom data exfiltration tool. However, by not sharing through your ISAC, you miss intelligence from peers that would have accelerated your timeline by 24 hours.

options.label: Focus exclusively on deep-dive malware reverse engineering and postpone IOC deployment until analysis is complete.
options.feedback_text: No, but… Your thorough reverse engineering produces a complete technical write-up of the malware family. However, the delay in deploying IOCs means the second-stage implant activates on two more machines before being detected.

options.label: Discard the memory dump as potentially corrupted and request a fresh forensic image instead.
options.feedback_text: No, and… The attacker's persistence mechanism triggers during the re-imaging process, wiping forensic artifacts from the original server. You've lost critical evidence. The investigation stalls for 48 hours while DFIR scrambles to reconstruct the timeline from network logs alone.

questions.context: HR is in crisis. 200 employees have received notification that their PII was exposed. Several employees are posting angry messages on internal Slack channels. Two employees have already contacted lawyers. The Chief People Officer wants guidance.
questions.text: How do you manage the internal employee crisis?

options.label: Hold a company-wide town hall, offer free identity monitoring for all employees, and establish a dedicated incident hotline staffed by trained counselors.
options.feedback_text: Yes, and… The town hall transparency calms the situation. Two employees who had contacted lawyers withdraw their inquiries after seeing the company's response. The identity monitoring benefit is later cited positively in the regulator's review of your incident response.

options.label: Send a detailed email to all employees explaining the situation and offer free credit monitoring services.
options.feedback_text: Yes, but… The email is well-received, but the lack of a face-to-face interaction feels impersonal to affected employees. Slack complaints continue at a reduced volume. Two senior engineers still submit their resignations.

options.label: Have HR reach out individually to the most vocal employees and offer them additional compensation.
options.feedback_text: No, but… The targeted approach calms the loudest voices, but other affected employees feel ignored and the selective treatment leaks to the press. However, the one-on-one conversations do prevent two potential lawsuits.

options.label: Lock down the internal Slack channels to prevent 'misinformation' and instruct HR to say nothing until legal approves messaging.
options.feedback_text: No, and… Censoring employees backfires spectacularly. Screenshots of the locked channels appear on social media within an hour. The story now becomes about your company silencing breach victims. A class-action lawsuit is filed the same day.

questions.context: Network monitoring shows suspicious DNS queries originating from the R&D subnet. The queries use DNS tunneling to exfiltrate data to an external server. R&D houses your most valuable trade secrets and upcoming product designs.
questions.text: How do you handle the potential R&D data exfiltration?

options.label: Immediately sinkhole the DNS tunneling domains, isolate the R&D subnet at Layer 3, and deploy a packet capture appliance to record the full exfiltration stream for evidence.
options.feedback_text: Yes, and… The sinkhole stops exfiltration in real-time. Packet captures reveal the attacker only got 12GB of the 200GB R&D archive. The captured traffic provides enough evidence for law enforcement to identify the threat actor's infrastructure.

options.label: Block the suspicious DNS destinations at the firewall and begin scanning R&D systems for compromise.
options.feedback_text: Yes, but… The DNS blocking stops the primary channel, but the attacker has a backup exfiltration method via HTTPS to a legitimate cloud storage service. You catch it 2 hours later. About 40GB was exfiltrated total.

options.label: Capture DNS traffic for analysis but don't block it yet — you want to understand the scope first.
options.feedback_text: No, but… While you analyze, another 30GB of data is exfiltrated. However, your analysis reveals the complete list of targeted files, which helps you understand exactly what the attacker was after and assess the true business impact.

options.label: Assume it's a false positive since R&D uses many external APIs and deprioritize the alert.
options.feedback_text: No, and… The full R&D archive — 200GB including unreleased product designs and patent applications — is exfiltrated overnight. The data appears on a competitor's development roadmap three months later. Your IP advantage is gone.
